content.body: tbh i'd say that if the catch is in a separate file from the finally, then the finally file probably shouldn't be assuming the promise is handled

* tbh i'd say that if the catch is in a separate file from the finally, then the finally file probably shouldn't be assuming the promise is handled - iow, the author of one file shouldn't assume knowledge of the code in another one

m.new_content.body: tbh i'd say that if the catch is in a separate file from the finally, then the finally file probably shouldn't be assuming the promise is handled - iow, the author of one file shouldn't assume knowledge of the code in another one

content.body: Hey! I have a random question: was the idea of `Array.prototype.clear()` ever struck down in TC39? I've had repeated experiences of `array.length = 0` not being trusted by developers, despite being the best way to do clear an array, so I was thinking if a `.clear()` proposal would have a future
content.formatted_body: Hey! I have a random question: was the idea of Array.prototype.clear() ever struck down in TC39? I've had repeated experiences of array.length = 0 not being trusted by developers, despite being the best way to do clear an array, so I was thinking if a .clear() proposal would have a future

content.body: Just coming from Python, Java, C#, Rust, or almost any language, you expect `.clear()`
content.formatted_body: Just coming from Python, Java, C#, Rust, or almost any language, you expect .clear()

content.body: Why would `.clear` be trusted more? Btw, you can also use `arr.splice(0, arr.length)`
content.formatted_body: Why would .clear be trusted more? Btw, you can also use arr.splice(0, arr.length)

content.body: It _seems_ sketchy, despite being valid, which is just an odd developer experience
content.formatted_body: It seems sketchy, despite being valid, which is just an odd developer experience

content.body: It felt much more like regular JS in 2014, but JS has improved so much in terms of the developer experience since ES6, that now it just feels out of place :D
For instance, of course `.indexOf() > -1` was and still is completely valid â€“ nonetheless `.includes()` is _the_ clear way of doing the same since it was added ES2016
content.formatted_body: For instance, of course .indexOf() > -1 was and still is completely valid â€“ nonetheless .includes() is the clear way of doing the same since it was added ES2016

content.body: Not to mention the edge-case where you have non-array-index extra properties in an array instance, which will not be cleared by `array.length = 0;`
content.formatted_body: Not to mention the edge-case where you have non-array-index extra properties in an array instance, which will not be cleared by array.length = 0;

content.body: would those be cleared by a `.clear()` method though?
content.formatted_body: would those be cleared by a .clear() method though?

content.body: Imo they should
I can think of arguments in either direction\
content.formatted_body: I can think of arguments in either direction\

content.body: * I can think of arguments in either direction

m.new_content.body: I can think of arguments in either direction

content.body: Well argument in favor of it is, if you *don't* want the behavior of clearing non-indexes, you can just resort back to the original length method
content.formatted_body: Well argument in favor of it is, if you don't want the behavior of clearing non-indexes, you can just resort back to the original length method

content.body: Thinking about it further, we could also take this further and invert it
`Map.prototype.clear` doesn't clear properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?
content.formatted_body: Map.prototype.clear doesn't clear properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?

content.body: * `Map.prototype.clear` doesn't remove properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?
content.formatted_body: * Map.prototype.clear doesn't remove properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?

m.new_content.body: `Map.prototype.clear` doesn't remove properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?
m.new_content.formatted_body: Map.prototype.clear doesn't remove properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?

content.body: While to Array there is the distinction between indexes and properties, from an Object perspective, both are just properties, so what if instead clear() was added as an Object method?
and it would just generically work on arrays

> <@abotella:igalia.com> `Map.prototype.clear` doesn't remove properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?

That was my thinking at first there yes
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @abotella:igalia.com
Map.prototype.clear doesn't remove properties on the map object -- is array different because the indices are actual properties in the object?
That was my thinking at first there yes

content.body: Hmm, non-index properties on arrays seems like a niche use case outside of well-defined bounds of behavior
I would stick to Map-like semantics of just emptying the collection
That's up for further discussion though I suppose
Well, do y'all know if the method sense as a proposal, or is there a reason why the idea is dead in the water?
* Well, do y'all know if the method makes sense as a proposal, or is there a reason why the idea is dead in the water?

m.new_content.body: Well, do y'all know if the method makes sense as a proposal, or is there a reason why the idea is dead in the water?

content.body: My idea now is that, since arrays don't need a special method to access their internal values due to being just regular object properties, we should just make a generic *object* clear() method, which just works generically on arrays by extension
content.formatted_body: My idea now is that, since arrays don't need a special method to access their internal values due to being just regular object properties, we should just make a generic object clear() method, which just works generically on arrays by extension

content.body: So it is less niche and actually implements a new ability (clearing objects without manual looping of deletions) that was not previously possible unlike just clearing arrays with `.length = 0`
content.formatted_body: So it is less niche and actually implements a new ability (clearing objects without manual looping of deletions) that was not previously possible unlike just clearing arrays with .length = 0

content.body: Well, if it clears non-indexes, then why wouldn't it also delete `.length`? ðŸ˜… That's a tricky bit
content.formatted_body: Well, if it clears non-indexes, then why wouldn't it also delete .length? ðŸ˜… That's a tricky bit

content.body:
It can be defined like so:
`Object.prototype.clear()` = Delete all **own**, **enumerable** properties of `this`

`.length` is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.
content.formatted_body:
It can be defined like so:
Object.prototype.clear() = Delete all own, enumerable properties of this

.length is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.

content.body: I think the semantics would be clearer language-wide if `.clear()` always meant â€“ clear collection. And `Object` is not necessarily the way of implementing a _collection_, given it's the building block for everything (e.g. if you want a mapping, well, `Map` is often the best option)
content.formatted_body: I think the semantics would be clearer language-wide if .clear() always meant â€“ clear collection. And Object is not necessarily the way of implementing a collection, given it's the building block for everything (e.g. if you want a mapping, well, Map is often the best option)

content.body: `Map` is often too verbose and unnecessary for quick mapping needs
content.formatted_body: Map is often too verbose and unnecessary for quick mapping needs

content.body: In terms of data structures Map and Object are essentially the same, so saying Objects aren't collections is a bit illogical imo
Map is just Object with fancier methods to manage it, no reason Object couldn't get some for itself
Although I did just realize .clear() in Object prototype would indeed be prone to a lot of conflicts and confusion so it'd be probably best as a static method
`Object.clear(arr)`
content.formatted_body: Object.clear(arr)

content.body: you'd also have to figure out what to do for own vs inherited properties
are you deleting non-enumerable properties as well?

> <@voidhedron:matrix.org> It can be defined like so:
> `Object.prototype.clear()` = Delete all **own**, **enumerable** properties of `this`
> 
> `.length` is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.

^
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @voidhedron:matrix.org

It can be defined like so:
Object.prototype.clear() = Delete all own, enumerable properties of this

.length is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.

^

content.body: Just own enumerable props, anything else would break prototypes and other things
it'd be a shallow clear, which follows suit with pretty much every other iterative operation in JS with the notable recent exception of the long awaited `structuredClone`
content.formatted_body: it'd be a shallow clear, which follows suit with pretty much every other iterative operation in JS with the notable recent exception of the long awaited structuredClone

content.body: so JS devs are already used to these kinds of operations being shallow I'd say

* It can be defined like so:
`Object.clear(obj)` = Delete all **own**, **enumerable** properties of `obj`

`.length` is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.
content.formatted_body:
*

It can be defined like so:
Object.clear(obj) = Delete all own, enumerable properties of obj

.length is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.

m.new_content.body:
It can be defined like so:
`Object.clear(obj)` = Delete all **own**, **enumerable** properties of `obj`

`.length` is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.
m.new_content.formatted_body:
It can be defined like so:
Object.clear(obj) = Delete all own, enumerable properties of obj

.length is non-enumerable, so it would be preserved.

content.body: `arr.splice(0)`
content.formatted_body: arr.splice(0)

content.body: so you're adding `arr.clear()` to accomplish `arr.splice(0)`.  does that seem worthwhile?
content.formatted_body: so you're adding arr.clear() to accomplish arr.splice(0). does that seem worthwhile?

content.body: I would say the answer is exactly the same as with adding `.includes()`
content.formatted_body: I would say the answer is exactly the same as with adding .includes()

content.body: point taken.  there were some additional considerations for includes that don't apply here.  in any case, I'm not against convenience methods, though I'm not convinced in this particular case that splice or length leave much to be desired
it's worth noting that additional methods on `Array.prototype` will face resistance in committee
content.formatted_body: it's worth noting that additional methods on Array.prototype will face resistance in committee

content.body:
(I haven't read the full thread, lots of messages since I last checked)
A few delegates said in the last meeting they're reluctant to add new methods to `Array.prototype` due to web compatibility issues we always have
content.formatted_body:
(I haven't read the full thread, lots of messages since I last checked)
A few delegates said in the last meeting they're reluctant to add new methods to Array.prototype due to web compatibility issues we always have

content.body: `Array.prototype.group` was changed in the last meeting to use static methods on Map and Object instead
content.formatted_body: Array.prototype.group was changed in the last meeting to use static methods on Map and Object instead

content.body: https://github.com/tc39/notes/blob/main/meetings/2023-05/may-16.md#arrayprototypegroup-rename-for-web-compatibility

ref 1: 
https://github.com/tc39/notes/blob/d2a0097ec28f18d221118577086e20f78c33b504/meetings/2023-05/may-16.md#speakers-summary-of-key-points-4

ref 2: 
https://github.com/tc39/notes/blob/d2a0097ec28f18d221118577086e20f78c33b504/meetings/2023-05/may-18.md#speakers-summary-of-key-points-3
generally speaking, I think "some developers feel that the syntax for doing a thing is sketchy" is not a good enough reason to add a new stdlib method
`.length = 0` is not obscure or difficult to understand for readers, so I don't see much reason to add a `.clear` to arrays
content.formatted_body: .length = 0 is not obscure or difficult to understand for readers, so I don't see much reason to add a .clear to arrays

content.body: matlokam: i wouldn't want to add any new mutating methods to Array, personally.
content.formatted_body: matlokam: i wouldn't want to add any new mutating methods to Array, personally.

content.body: * matlokam: i wouldn't want to add any new mutating methods to Array, personally. if you want an empty array, `[]` is right there :-)
content.formatted_body: * matlokam: i wouldn't want to add any new mutating methods to Array, personally. if you want an empty array, [] is right there :-)

content.body: I think assigning to `length` is at least somewhat obscure. For most collections `length` doesn't have a setter. Having parity with other collections makes sense to me.
content.formatted_body: I think assigning to length is at least somewhat obscure. For most collections length doesn't have a setter. Having parity with other collections makes sense to me.

content.body: for most collections you can't use syntax to read from it either
generally not prohibitive, but this won't work with `const`, so not always an option
content.formatted_body: generally not prohibitive, but this won't work with const, so not always an option

content.body: Right, there was a conscious decision to not carry that forward. I don't think that disqualifies adopting more modern APIs for the older collection type though.
I generally see APIs as being _worse_ than syntax, though
content.formatted_body: I generally see APIs as being worse than syntax, though

content.body: Like I'd prefer people not write `array.at(5)` even though that's more consistent with what you'd do with a Map
content.formatted_body: Like I'd prefer people not write array.at(5) even though that's more consistent with what you'd do with a Map

content.body: similarly I'd prefer people not write `array.clear()` even though that's more consistent with what you'd do with a Map
content.formatted_body: similarly I'd prefer people not write array.clear() even though that's more consistent with what you'd do with a Map

content.body: I don't think it's really a matter of what's "more modern". Arrays are just a more foundational type and so have somewhat different affordances

I agree that writing to `length` is somewhat obscure and so it wouldn't be bad to have a duplicate API around it. But also I don't understand why this method would be important/useful enough to be worth the high cost of adding Array methods.
content.formatted_body: I agree that writing to length is somewhat obscure and so it wouldn't be bad to have a duplicate API around it. But also I don't understand why this method would be important/useful enough to be worth the high cost of adding Array methods.

content.body: Another reason I think making it a generic Object static method would be more worthwhile and easier to get going
It wouldn't go anywhere near Array but still be able to serve the task desired at hand, while also having other possible use-cases with non-arrays
idk, I think it's generally not a good idea to encourage folks to treat Arrays like general objects API-wise (I think this doesn't match most JS developers' intuition)
I also don't want to encourage people to clear properties from objects
there are cases where that is the right thing but they are few and far between

> <@littledan:matrix.org> idk, I think it's generally not a good idea to encourage folks to treat Arrays like general objects API-wise (I think this doesn't match most JS developers' intuition)

That's a fair point, and I kind of agree I suppose, but on the other hand there is plenty of existing stuff in the language that does that already, so i dunno it would just be 1 more to the pile

In reply to @littledan:matrix.org
idk, I think it's generally not a good idea to encourage folks to treat Arrays like general objects API-wise (I think this doesn't match most JS developers' intuition)
That's a fair point, and I kind of agree I suppose, but on the other hand there is plenty of existing stuff in the language that does that already, so i dunno it would just be 1 more to the pile

content.body:
> <@bakkot:matrix.org> I also don't want to encourage people to clear properties from objects

content.body: Yeah and then my answer is, that is not worth having, vs just writing `arr.length = 0`
content.formatted_body: Yeah and then my answer is, that is not worth having, vs just writing arr.length = 0

content.body: Yeah I think, if we decide this kind of manipulation is important to support more intuitively, `Array.clear` is a good place to put it.
content.formatted_body: Yeah I think, if we decide this kind of manipulation is important to support more intuitively, Array.clear is a good place to put it.
